> I think Jan's point about using Expect headers is a good one. I, for
> one, have never used Expect as a request header on POST or PUT [1] to
> check for server compliance. Anyone have a living example of this?

AFAIK, while it's doable from the client side of things on .net, IIS takes
over the 100 response, making server processing impossible. I've yet to find
a way to override this behaviour without going down in unmanaged code.

Seb
